title: Astro Teller
text:
Eric "Astro" Teller (born 29 May 1970) is a British-American entrepreneur, <a href="computer%20scientist">computer scientist</a>, and author, with expertise in the field of intelligent technology.
Early life and education.
Teller was born in <a href="Cambridge">Cambridge</a>, England, and raised in <a href="Evanston%2C%20Illinois">Evanston</a>, <a href="Illinois">Illinois</a>, US. He is the son of Paul Teller, who was an instructor in the philosophy of science at the <a href="University%20of%20Illinois%20at%20Chicago">University of Illinois at Chicago</a> and Chantal DeSoto, a buyer and clothing designer for <a href="Sears">Sears</a> who later became a teacher of <a href="gifted">gifted</a> children. His grandparents include both French economist and mathematician <a href="G%C3%A9rard%20Debreu">Gérard Debreu</a> and Hungarian-born American theoretical physicist <a href="Edward%20Teller">Edward Teller</a>. He received the nickname "Astro" after high school friends compared his flat-top haircut to <a href="AstroTurf">AstroTurf</a>, and he reportedly had the image of cartoon dog <a href="Astro%20%28The%20Jetsons%29">Astro</a> from "<a href="The%20Jetsons">The Jetsons</a>" painted on his car door in college.
Teller holds a Bachelor of Science in <a href="computer%20science">computer science</a> from <a href="Stanford%20University">Stanford University</a>, Masters of Science in <a href="symbolic%20computation">symbolic computation</a> (symbolic and <a href="heuristic">heuristic</a> computation), also from Stanford, and a PhD in <a href="artificial%20intelligence">artificial intelligence</a> from <a href="Carnegie%20Mellon%20University">Carnegie Mellon University</a>, where he was a recipient of a Hertz fellowship.
Career.
After working as a teacher at Stanford, he became a business executive.
Since 2010, Teller has been directing <a href="Google%20X">Google X</a> (which has become X) laboratories. Projects at Google X include <a href="Google%20Glass">Google Glass</a>, <a href="Waymo">Google driverless car</a>, <a href="Google%20Contact%20Lens">Google Contact Lens</a>, and <a href="Project%20Loon">Project Loon</a>. Google X spun its project called Flux out into a stand-alone business in 2012. Teller gave a <a href="TED%20%28conference%29">TED Talk</a> at TED2016 on the importance of failure in Google X's approach to pioneering new projects. On 18 October 2016, it was announced that Teller would temporarily be in charge of X's Project Wing while the search for its next permanent leader was underway.
In 2017, Teller was honored with an <a href="Edison%20Awards">Edison Achievement Award</a> for his commitment to innovation throughout his career.
Entrepreneur.
Teller was the co-founder and chairman of <a href="BodyMedia">BodyMedia</a>, makers of the BodyMedia FIT, Bodybugg, and Sensewear armbands (wearable devices that measure sleep, perspiration, motion, and calories burned).
He is also co-founder, director, and former CEO of Cerebellum Capital.
Speaker.
In May 2001, Teller was featured on <a href="NPR">NPR</a>'s radio program "<a href="All%20Things%20Considered">All Things Considered</a>", discussing how the good economy has shaped the attitudes of 30-year-olds towards their jobs. Teller is the co-founder and co-host of the Solve for X annual event and internet community.
He has lectured at the <a href="TEDMED">TEDMED</a> Conference (2003 and 2004), <a href="South%20By%20Southwest">South By Southwest</a> (2013), and ideaCity (2004). In 2008, he appeared as a political commentator on the national French television station <a href="France%2024">France 24</a>.
Author.
Teller's novel, "Exegesis", was published in 1997. It was translated into Dutch, Japanese, Danish, German, Italian, and <a href="Greeklish">Greeklish</a>.
A second novel, "Among These Savage Thoughts", was published in 2006. An experimental novel, it deals with the protagonist's journey to reinvent himself in the imaginary mountain society of Karabas.
His third book, "Sacred Cows", is a non-fiction work examining society's attitudes about marriage and divorce, co-written with his wife Danielle Teller. It was published by Diversion Books in 2014 and in the same year he gave a TEDxBoston talk on the book.
Personal life.
Teller is married to Danielle Teller.
